sp.p: Peace thou brat, whose mouth is armed with bale of dice, instead of a stall of teeth. What pratest thou of recovering lost rings and money? The shi● wracke that thou makest is vnrecoverable.
sp.stage: Nec reuocare potes, qui: periere, dies
sp.p: Lost dayes can never be recalled. Time steals away, as thou art a stealer of time. See now how thou hast incroached vpon my pretious time, whilst I heare a● speake, with such a canker of good houres. Away away.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: You bid me away, because you dare not play with mee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Dost thou dare me thou elfe? I will.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p:
I know you'le venture no money, nor points.
must play with you for nothing. Come on therefore at hide and seeke, or blinde man buffe.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Come, I will once boy it againe at either for a crash

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Why then at blindman buffe you shall bee first blinded.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay sir boy, if you challenge and choose the game too, you must be first blinded. But what tooles haue wee?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Borrow one of these Gentlewomens maskes:

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay then you will looke through the holes. Will you gull me so?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: If I once looke through the holes, then say Ludio is set in the Pillory. but rather then want ●ew, here take my garter, and tye my sachell about my face.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: O with what wicked bumbast is his sachell slust? I thought it was not true begotten bookes, that made the belly of it swell so bigge.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: It has cast calfe now. You must tye mee to these winckers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I had rather tye thee to one of our schoole posts, or hang our great dicsnary at thy heele, for a clogge to keepe thee from gadding to play.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Talke not to me of Dick snary, nor Richard-snary; I care not how little I come neare them. But sir you must haue this Morice-bell tied to your point, that I may heare where you goe. Else you will haue too much oddes of me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Will you make me act hobby horse, or Master Gingle? For once I will.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Now that is on, come and tye me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: So, you are tyed, now I must turne you about thrice. Sic deluditur Ludre. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p:
I doe not heare the bell. Lauriger stands still I
doubt. Nay gentle playfellow, you must stirre vp and downe, ●e we shall haue no sport.

sp.speaker: Sirea.
sp.p: I Hope to finde more game here. O yonder's a ●h gamester. I think he is caught in our net already. So, so, Verily Cupid hath blinded him for our purpose.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: O I haue him. I haue him. But where is your bell? vntye me now It is your 〈◊〉 to be blinded O what ha●d 〈◊〉 Vndow me, vndoe me.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: I haue but the vndoing of many in my dayes. But I neuer met with so forward a guest, that would begge his owne vndoing.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I haue ouer come it now. What now? Hee turn'd to Shee? Master Lauriger, me thinkes your lookes are grown very long on the sodain. Has he seru'd me thus?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: How well art thou seru'd, when such a Nimph is at thy seruice?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: If thou be at my seruice, s●ake thy silken coate, and golden band, against my garters and hat. Lift who shall deale.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: Itell thee, I vse little plaine dealing. I must shuffle and cut too.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Both? Nay that's against law.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: Yet will i deale plainely with thee. I haue neither skill nor minde to play with thee.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Can any sweet Nimph be a stranger to Ludio? I haue heard that Nimphs loue to play at more games then I know.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: I doe not refuse, because thou art a stranger, but because thou art our friend; Thou art ours already. What need wee spend birdlime vpon those wanton sparrowes, that are in our cage already? S●t cosin Ludio, thou art a member of our family Queene He done gets good accesse by thee. Goe on with all thy thrifty wares to get in more letters vp in our trade. Goe to sir Grobiano, make him pay for thy acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Gentle goldilockes. I would doe so, but that I am now imployed against my woont in studying an oration to saue my head from a blow, which Apollos visitation may now bring vpon me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: NOuice, you know you must appeare too.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: I haue cited him according to law.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: What is the matter, thinke you?

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: I heard a bird sing (hearke in your eare) that theres an accusation against you for misspending your time with Captaine Complement.

sp.speaker: No
sp.p: I doe but as others doe. I am not alone.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What strange guest is yon? A female I thinke. Who but Siren that has made such turmoiles here of late. Praco haue you cited her?

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p:
Shee's in my ●owle, I'me glad I haue met with her. Dame Siren, thou art indited by the name of Siren for subuerting Apollos subiects; You must along with mee, and appeare to answer such matters
as shall be obiected against you, on the behalfe of our Soueraigne Lord Apollo.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: Thou arrest me, who haue arrested thy betters? I tell thee, I will be there. I haue good friends in Apollos Court. I will not be hired to tarry away. But before I goe, I must deliuer a message to you from a great goddesse.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: A goddesse to mee?

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: I●o thee, and thee, and to you all.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Say what thou must, or canst.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.l: Hedone, Queene Hedone, sweet Hedone,
Dame natures care, and noblest birth,
The ioy, and crowne of heauen, and earth,
The aime, and center of desire,
The fuell of most sacred fire,
By me, and this, and this
She sends you all her blisse.
Among the gods she hath her place,
They all stand gazing on her face.
The clouds do from her presence flye,
'Tis sunshine where she casts her eye.
Where are she treads on earth below,
A rose or lilly vp doth grow.
Her breath a gale of spi● brings:
Mute are the Muses when she sings.
What ere she touches turnes to Nectar,
What man, but can, and must affect her?
No heart so hard, but needes must melt,
When once her kindely warmth is felt.
She, she vouchsafe, to call you to her,
And wooing prayes you now to wooe her.
By study soone, fresh youth doth breake,
The faire grow foule, the strong grow weake:
Leaue leaue this musing bookish trade:
Inioy your selues before youth fade.
Time must be gone,
Old age creepes on.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: She puts her message home, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: I haue arrested her; and I thinke shee will arrest vs.

sp.speaker: Nouice.
sp.p: I like her song well, I'le get a coppy of it. If Apollo giue me leaue, I will haue more acquaintance with her. Me thinkes this Siren would make a good wife for my Master, Captaine Complement, and so she shall be my Mistresse. O faire Hedone, sweet honey Hedone, more sweet then Marmalet, or Quidony.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Away thou glosing flatterer. Wee are no game for thee. Let vs about our businesse. Praeco doe your office, carry her away. Let her chant this song before Apollo. The Muses will out-sing her, and teare her flearing lockes. I will goe cite Slug. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: GEntle sir Gingle, the flowre of my schoole, returne my thankes to the honourable Dame Indulgence thy high deseruing Mother, for the glittering token the sent me. I shall deserue it in my readinesse to accomplish thee. But where ended we yesterday?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: You were instructing me how to salute a Lady, or so, if she had a Monkey, or so, and wept, or so.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: This is but so, so.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: In case you finde a Lady weeping and mournfull, for that her Monkey is sicke of the mumps, then say.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Faire Lady weepe not for your Monkey.

sp.speaker: Comp
sp.p: This is bare and vulgar. Rather Ash your salutation thus. 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 Claridiana.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: ●t as can be. T● is Claridiana was courted by the Knight of the sunne. My Mother has ●ad that booke to me. Sir your s●le is very h●h and lo●.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Ves sir, my master and I haue gone ouer many as high a stile, when we went to robbe orchards for our dinners.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Twise double worthy dubbed Maddame—

sp.speaker: Giag.
sp.p: Twise dobble dubbed. What doth shee weare a doublet doe Ladies ●e to weare doublets now?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You vnderstand not. There was of late yeeres a fashion, when haec vir, & hic mulier were in request. But gentle Gingle, though thou dost stand vnder me, yet thou dost not vnderstand me. Twise doubly because she hath two titles to her honour. The full a title of law which shee hath from ●et Qu band who was dubbed Knight with an vnbloody sword. The second The second What ●'st. him h●, the second. Oh I haue it, because the is rich● in cloathes then in ioynter. But proceed we in your approach.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Oh so you haue wonderfully inlighted inlighted me.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I haue wipe ●and clarified the dull spectacle of thy intellect with the Napkin of my Comment.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Indeed now me thinks espye her clearely without a looking-glasse. But how should I forbid her to weep?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: To weepe? Madame I forbid the banes betweene you and snow.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I, the Knights name Sorrow?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Perhaps hee's a o●y knight, (like my master)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What Imp. you are too nimble. Are you so saucy to step before me?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: (I was saine to step before him when we stole hens together, and he put me first into the henn-roost.)

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Truely Captaine me thinkes Implement suggests very 〈◊〉 would willingly forbid those banes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Forbidding banes? Away with this forbidding banes. It is a banefull ominous word, not befitting the wooing stile. You shall mould all vp in the fine pulle past of poetry thus.
Twice double worthy dubbed Madame,
Whose vertues not the longest tongue can fadome.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I thinke Ladies garments are measured by th'ell and by the yard, but measuring their vertues by the fadome, I neuer heard of before.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Twice double worthy dubbed Madame, Whose long tongue no man can fadome.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O dismall. O dangerous! Take heed of stumbling so with your tongue when you speake of female tongues. Whose vertues not the longest tongue can fadome.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Whose vertues not the longest tongue can fadome.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Right and streight. Then on.
Souse not thy glittering globy eyne
In dreary teary salt sea brine.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Globy eyne? What's that?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Know'st thou not what globy is? I perceiue then thou a● no traueller, thou hast not (as I haue done) trauelled about the globe of the earth. Know'st not what eyne be? I see thou art no Poet, thou hast neuer read Chaucer. Hast thou neuer heard of eyne twaine?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Souse not. This word will not downe with me.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Mr. Gingles queasie stomacke cannot disgest souse.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: The Lady will thinke, I vse to conuerse with Tripewiues, if I talke to her of souse.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Mr you once courted a sousing Dame, (a fulsome Kitchinwench.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Peace thou squeaking pigge; or else the bandogs of these hands shall lugge thy lagging eares. Souse not thy globy eyne. I tell thee this is not such as it is vulgarly taken. It is not a butcherly word, it is not descended from the Tripe wife, nor hath it affinity with the fryingpan.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Nor did it euer hang cheeke by iole with a blacke pudding.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Marke the Philosophy of the phrase. The roaring dashing element, the sea is salt, and brine is salt, and trickling teares are salt.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: And P. I. S. is salt.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: The sea, the bryne, the teares, the teares, the bryne, the sea. Why may they not all three thus dashing, soaking, soucing lye? It is a martiall word. I vse it often my selfe, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I too often when you tell me you'le giue me a souse on the eare.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Souse not, &c. Fit. wondrous fit, as my persumed gloue for my sweethand. It shee wept for sorrow before, I shall now make her weepe for ioy to heare this eloquence.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: But my Masters, you leaue the poore Monkey too long in distresse. Heelle dye o'th Mumpes, vnlesse we relieue him the sooner.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: 'Tis true. Pray goe on. I am to say your Monkey will recouer. Master Prompter doe your part.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Then thus. Your soure leg'd, two-leg'd, Man-imitating, two-handed, long-tayled play fellow, shall be readuanced to his pristine integrity of limbs.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: He had need put in sound of winde and limb, for the Mumps lay siege to his throate, and breed more danger to his weazand, then to his tenne bones.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Two-foot, foure-foot? how can that be? Hath hee sixe feet?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Sixe feet? sixe to one my Master puts the tricke of the louse vpon him. I haue knowne when hee has blowne them in a quill vpon better men this this.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou art not worthy to be numbred among the two-footed, but rather art to bee imbased vnto the foure-footed. If thou dost not vnderstand how Apes and Monkeyes are two-leg'd and two-handed; sometime they creepe on all foure. Imp. shew him how, sometime they stalke on tiptoe. Thus.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: If I had bin an Ape I should haue climed plum-trees brauely.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Let me see how you can imitate this.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Sometime they trace on all foure thus.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Sometime they ride vpon a mastiffe dogge thus. I want nothing now but my whippe to keepe this Lollard hound in awe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Come off Imp. Enough of this. We will send him hereafter for instruction to Paris Garden, where hee shall learne not onely Ape trickes, but the whipping of blinde Beares.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Paris Garden? O fine Paris they say is a one City in France. I am glad he will send mee thither. No man can be a compleat Gentleman till he haue learnt their cringes and crinkling i'th hams: which is in excellent request to the heauens now adayes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Good sir, I hope my selfe, and such men of worth as I, haue transported thence already plentifull loads of this French ware, that you shall saue the labour and cost of liuing there at their deare Ordinaries and pretious dancing-schooles, you must therefore in your stipend to me allow me, for that which I spent among Counts, Nobles, Knights and Monsiers there; sometime it'h fiue pound Ordinary, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: An horrible profitable lye My Master ne're dyn'd there but with O●llers and Vintners boyes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell you it cost me soure Nobles to the Vsher of the dancing schoole to learne one tricke, which they cal Le Tourne fuseau It wheeles a man about, as a boy does a stone in a ho●pe, and makes him appeare as round and vniforme, as a Ioyners turn'd bed post.

sp.speaker: Gins.
sp.p: I pray you learne me that whirlegig tricke.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You are not come to that. Be not so hasty, you are yet but in the Rudiments, and to tell you plaine, you must refund to me some charge for other proficiency before we aspire so high.
There was another vaulting tricke called the our.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: The base vulgar in English call it the hoister.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: It lifts a man vp till he grow lesse and lesse like a Hawke after a Heron. Shaw. It cost me. Let me see.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: how much?

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Vpon mine honour thirty Crownes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I thinke it was but twenty.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: By your leaue master, I know better then you. Doe not I keepe your Count Booke? I'me sure 'twas that weeke that you bought the Iewellers rich Diamond that was refused by so many Nobles. They could not reach the price of it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O it was the late Queene Mothers Iewell. Thou didst still thou forgetfull brat to leaue it behinde. I should haue worne it at this publike show. All Parnassus would haue admired it.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Master, you lost the key of your Cabinet. I durst not breake it ope (The diuell a Iewell we haue, but one that was bought of a Pedlar, and in the Country Townes he makes a great show with it at Beare. baitings, but in such ciuill places as this is, he durst not be seene with it.)

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I pray you when I am i'th humour of buying Iewels, let me haue the refusall of it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou shalt, because thou art an ingenious Gentleman 〈◊〉 Imp. Remember to set downe a caueat in the Margent of my Inuentary, that no man else ●y so much as looke on it or haue any price set of it.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Master Gingle I pray you pay me ten groats for entring this Caueat in mine office. My fee my fee sir.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Come to me at my lodging, and I will lay salt on this birds oyle dor feare of flying away.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell you Master Gingle. It will goe neere to cost you the manner of Foolingham.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Let oakes and lands flye. I meane to glitter bright in Diamond▪ dearely dight.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You must adde.
That men and dames may gaze, and say,
What starre is that, that glides along this way?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: What starts is that, &c O excell● All the world could neuer haue furnisht me with such a Tutor.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Say rather all the habitable circumference of this muddy masly earthy globe could not haue affoorded and suppeditated vnto me so mellifluous an Indoctrinator, as is the curious Captaine Complement.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O that I could by Metamorphasis be transformed into this eloquent man.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Thou hadst better bee transformed with Apuleius into a golden Asse.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell thee I haue written a large booke of instructions how a man should weare his cloaths, on which side his purse should lye in his pocket, which stocking he should draw on first vpon ominous dayes.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Indeed sir I haue heard you often tell of a man that brake his legge because hee pul'd on his left stocking first on one of the dogge dayes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I sirra, and there was another, that had the tooth-ach seuen yeeres after, because he pickt his teeth with the south end of his picktooth, in stead of the north, while he was in his chamber meditating a discourse to be offred vp before a beuy of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Is there south and north a picktooth?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I, it was touched with a loadstone.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I would rather haue pickt my teeth with my knife thus, then haue runne into such a mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What say you? what doe you? doe you weare a knife about you?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I'me sure it cost mee a Marke, and I got mine armes grauen vpon the blade, three hobby-horses or, prancing in a field▪ or, bridled and sadled argent.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Then I must n●s tell you my minde. I hop'd well that you would proue vnder my hands, but now I doubt you are no Gentleman, I feare youle neuer proue fashionable, I will rather imploy my paines about other my schollars who haue vowed neuer to weare kniues.
What? weare a knife. Nay I haue done with you.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Nay, good sir, I pray you doe not cast me off, I'le rather cast away this clownish toole.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I may take it vp and weare it. No knife can wound my gentry.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: We burne day light. I must hast, and muster vp my friends and aduocates to plead for mee in this Court. Sirra Imp. runne to Mistresse Gingle, tell her, now 'tis time.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I will be your Remembrancer to her: Shee shall protect you, else she is no mother for me.

sp.speaker: Geron with a forke on's necke.
sp.p: I Haue bin mending my hedges, which the scuruy boy Ludio broake downe. And now when I would rest at home, and take my nooning-nap, I must bee vexed with my sonne, my wretched sonne. They say that Apollo keepes visitation to day. I will lay my sonne at his Pallace gate, perhaps this feast day wee may get some fauour, some drop of his clemency. Exit.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: IV. ge Rubbish What Iugge? bring away the looking glasse. Thou dirty Rubbish, thy singers haue defiled the lace of my Cuffes. Will not cuffing about the eares make you more cleanly?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: The lace is so thicke, that I was faine to tugge hard at it. I know not what can foule it, vnlesse the smoothing-iron cast a rusty colour through the paper

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p: Out vpon thee for an old rusty lyer. The glasse▪ Hold it on the other side. You know I doe not loue to behold that moule on this cheeke. Thou spitefull baggage, more yet on the left hand. Is that the left hand?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: Heere's my left hand.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p:
I, but the other side is my left hand. You must conforme
your eyes and hands to your▪ Mistresse, and forget which is your owne right or left. Do's my Vaile hang in true proportion?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: I can say nothing for any portion, but in hangs iust behinde you.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: Vnlesse I be set all in print, the Poeticall Muse will make times on me, when they see mee in A● Iudgement Hall. But Iugge, what had my sonne to breakefast this morning?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: A Pullets wing.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: That's not forsooth. What nothing else?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: Forsooth a piece of Pye too But so sooth Mistresse, if you giue me leaue, I'le tell you what they say of him.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: What? who? Why?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: Marry forsooth Philoponus, and others eke also do say, if you feed him so much, that he will neuer proue: a scholler.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: Proue scholler? Doe they thinke my childe is so low borne as to be made a ●y scholler? Shall such a keene refin'd wit be dul'd and imbased, by plodding on a booke? What is Philoponus but a Bookeworme, an Inckhorne squirt, a botching patcher of Latin shred● What is this learning, but a little gibberish in the tongue, a sheepish looke in the face, and pennilesse famine in the purse? I he more schollar a young man is, the lesse like to speed of a rich wife. I will haue my sonne the marke and wish of the most renowned Dames.

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: I doe not so hate schollars, but that I could one in my heart to marry Philoponus at a venture.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p:
I will, as mannerly as I may, tell Apollo that it is an honour to his schoole, that such a one as my sonne was of it, though but for a tast of the Muses dish, a
gentle touch of the verge of their garment. I, but is my Coach ready?

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: One of the horses is very vnruly, the Coachman. talkes like a rogue, and sayes that nothing but a wise will tame him.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: This lewd horse-rubbers tongue must be tam'd I doubt he is three quarters drunke.

sp.speaker: Iug.
sp.p: That's no newes.

sp.speaker: Indul.
sp.p: I must away, the houre runnes with swifter race then my horses. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quartus. Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Geron and Retro his sonne.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: KEepe on thy way, dost thou not see? hold on that path. Seest thou not how my staffe doth wise thee the way? I thinke thou cam'st backward into the world, that now art dam'd to this crab-like pace. Shall I neuer be rid of this office? So: stand still Now me thinkes I see the portch of great Apollos temple. O great Apollo, if my sonne haue thus deserued to be punished, yet what hath guiltlesse Geron, what hath he offended?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: O. terg. ollota nodrap. su.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Thou dost well to humble thy selfe before great Apollo. But why to pardon vs? Why me?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Rethaf, O. rethaf.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What sayest thou to thy Father?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Ti. saw. ruoy. tlaf.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What sayest thou? Was it my fault?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Voy. tes. em. ta. ot. ih, a koob.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Did I set you at too high a booke? You were too proud of your wit, and would needes slide ouer the rudiments, and leape at first into an higher forme, then your capacity would reach vnto.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Im. rehtom. Im. ●thom.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Thy Mother, thy Mother. I, it is true, thy Mother would needes haue it so. I must needs say 'twas her fault, not mine. She euer ioggd me, and told mee, that her Rowland was as good a schollar, as his Master, and that the 〈◊〉 est booke did best befit his ●gh flowne 〈◊〉 and now alas thy long long punishment penance vnto me, then to thy two yeeres haue I bin 〈◊〉 at home. It grieues & grates mee eares to heare this backward language imposed by Apollos doome on my wretched childe. It wounds mine eyes to see these backward steps. And yet remaines a furtiuer time for me,
sp.l: To be the scorne and by word of this place.
Old Gerons ouer-forward childe
Retorted for his hastinesse,
Is made the prou● 〈◊〉 of these times.
And likened to soone ripe soone rotten fruit▪
But how long time remaines yet vnexpir'd
〈◊〉 this vnnaturall preposterous taske?
〈◊〉 ●o. Rey. Say. Norey.
〈◊〉 I, so, it is one whole liuelong yeere.
●ich thy poore father (spent with teares and grief)
Scarce hopes now to outlast. Alas
The candle of my dayes is almost spent,
It waueth in the snufte, and little oyle
Is left to make it flame.
And yet alas too soone these blasts of sighes
Will puffe it out▪ ●ese teares will drowne it quite.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Rethaf. reed. Rethaf.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What sayest thou my deere sonne, too deere to me, that hast me cost so deepe a punishment.

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Tel. su. geb so. old pa.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Well What shall we begge of Apollo?

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Ot, nodrap. su. sibt. ●ey.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: To pardon this yeere to vs, and release thee? I feare thy wishes are farre larger then our hopes.

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Irrem. ollopa.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Merry Apollo? I doubt his eares are stopt, and I haue heard the gods vse not to recall their doomes, which they haue once pronounced.

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Keps. of suesu●n.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What? wouldest thou haue me speake to Musaeus Apollos Priest, to intercede for thee for this remission?

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Os ot. mih.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l: IN good time here he comes forth.
But sonne I dare not approach to him.
O what a trembling reuerence doth possesse
My limbs, and all benums my chill cold blood,
When I behold his awefull grauity.
Let vs retire beside this shady tree
This mossy bancke will rest my weary limbs,
And giue me time to recollect my spirits.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Graue guide of tender youth, Interpreter
Of great Apollos lawes chiefe secretary
Vnto the learned Muses, all your words
Are lodged safe in this laborious breast.
Thinke your command's no sooner said then done▪

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.l: Carefull Philoponus, I approue your paines
And haue already recommended you
Vnto Apollos selfe. O that the rest
Of those, that vndertake this worthy taske,
Pretending to the liberall sciences,
Could so acquit themselues.
But 〈◊〉 all seeing 〈◊〉 in circling round
About both Hemispheares of this large world,
Hath spy'd that some (O too too great a summe)
Haue s●ly crept within the verge and pa●
Of his dominions. In truth they strangers are,
Nay enemies and rebels to his lawes;
Yet would be counted Natiues of his schoole,
By them his tender plants corrupted are,
Distorted, bruised, hindred of their growth.
Thinke they that these foundations haue bin l●
These Cells erected, and those Temples dight
To harbour such foule el●es? Shall snorting sloath
Thinke here to nestle, fixed to his bed,
As is the slow-pac'd snaile vnto his shell?
Shall wanton pleasure thinke to reuell here?
Shall toying apish prating Complement
Outface the Muses, teare Apollos lockes,
Intice away the tender brood, with showes
Of empty words, and bubbles vanishing?
Shall shifting sharkes defraud their innocence?
Shall hasty heady Nouices outleap their masters lo●,
Presuming on their wit, and vndertake
To read a lecture to their teacher? No.
'Tis well that some haue heretofore for this
Bin made examples of such hastinesse.
Nay let them backward goe, that thus haue runne.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l: Alas poore childe, I see, he meaneth thee.
Haue pitty on vs great Apollos Priest.
Worthy Philoponus intreat Mus●us for my childe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Do'es your childe desire so much?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: D●g. ris keps. ros. em.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Speake for him good sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: His language is so harsh, that I will speake, if it be but to rid my eares of this preposterous sound. Venerable Mus●us. May it please our Lord Apollo, now after two yeers penance to remit the remaining yeer.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: If there be euidence that in this time, he hath retir'd and plyed what formerly he ouerslipped in his rudiments.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: My selfe can partly witnesse that.

sp.speaker: Muscus.
sp.p: It may be that Apollo will consider him. But let vs hast vp to Pernassus top. The time is come, the Court must now begin.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: My heart is warme with hope to follow them.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: STill I say and sweare vpon my vertues, that you are mistaken. Haue you bin so long my schollar, and are you yet vnacquainted with the Callender of my stipend booke?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: My bargaine was to allow you fiue crownes a moneth, and will you now wire-draw mee to thirteene moneths i'th yeere? When I was Apollos schollar, I'me sure Musaeus reckoned but quarterly, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 but twelue moneths i'th yeere.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Apollos Priest must follow his Masters walke, the sunnes yeerely passage through the twelue signes of the Zodiake. I will haue nothing to doe with Astronomy.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I, but our Almanackes euery yeere reckon but twelue moneths.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What dost thou tell me of Almanackes? Vsurers goe by the Almanacke. I scorne that griping trade. My moneth is foure weekes ●ust, you may remember them by the changing your shirts, euery fourth shirt determines my pay.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I reckon the moneth by one shirt.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Who shall be iudge betweene vs?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Iudge betweene vs? Am not I thine instructer▪ I'le be thy iudge. For euery one of my moneths I teach thee a severall straine of Courtesie And so thou hast of me in the yeere, documents accordingly, thirteene to the dozen.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: My Masters father was a Baker, and therefore he allowes an odde call of courtesie, neatly chipt.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Si●a Imp. draw out the Catalogue and number them.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: The first moneth, the Semicircle.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I, with my hat thus. To make iust halfe a circumference.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Remember alwaies the drop withall.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: In my motion, my gold hatband must fall downe, thus.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I cry fallings: this is my fee, I trow.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: It is an excellent embleme, and signifies that for loue of your friend, you will cast away your gold, and trample it vnder your feet, and that's the reason that Gentlemen now adayes weare their hatbands loose. Register proceed.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: The second moneth the Calue-claspe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Performe it with Imp. that I may view you the better. Doe you remember that in arching your arme ouer his shoulder, you must neuer touch his band or garment behinde, but apprehend the calfe with your first touch intirely.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I warrant you, I am old dogge at that.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: If I had knowne you had bin an old dogge, I would not haue trusted you with my Calfe. Ba.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: And before I dismisse the calfe, I giue it the gentle nip or prasye thus.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Ba, ba. No Butcher nips a Calfe more neatly in the rumpe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Which shewes your feruency of loue, that you are loath to be vnclasped from your friends intimity.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I haue it to a haire.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Register walke on your monethly pace.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: The third moneth, the gentle shrug.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I must tell you, you haue not got that perfect yet.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Not my shrugge sir? That was my last lesson.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Indeed sir I was by, when Signior Gosso in that action smiled, and asked if you were not lowsie.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O there's your fault, gentle Gingle. A hundred to one you shrugged but with one shoulder.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I would aduise you hereafter to shrugge by a looking-glasse, that you may see after what manner you doe it.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Indeed my looking-glasse is broken with dancing with it in my hand, to marke the postures of my face when I caper'd. But I'le buy another.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, you must buy two, that one may reflect vpon the other, and then may you at once see your motion in your shrugge both before and behinde.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p:
O excellent! for this double glasse, I'le giue you
a double fee. But, I pray you sir, wherein is my shrug faulty?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: My deare schollar, thou must know, there are diuers kindes of shrugges, there is the Misers shrugge, and that is accompanied with the scratching of the elbow: there is the Beggars shrugge, and that's done with a quicke motion, snatching, to make a sixe▪ footed bandogge leaue his hold.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: My Master and I act that at home sometimes, when we are loath to part with an old friend, our linnen.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: There is a winter shrugge, and that's performed with the hands insconced in a Muste, & a Foxe-furr'd co● close gift. There is a drowsie shrugge, and that sometime befals a gallant, when he has set vp al night at Cards, and sau'd the pulling off his boo●es. This shrugge is commonly performed with displaying out the armes, and yawning with the mouth, which represents a kinde of Libbards face. And lastly, there is a gentle Italian shrugge.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I pray you sir let me goe with you Let mee see. The Misers shrugge, the winter shrugge, the drowsie shrugge, the lousie shrugge. I shall hardly carry away all these.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, you must carry away none of these. You must leaue them all behinde you. The last and onely gentle shrugge, is your Italian shrugge.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O the Italian shrugge. There 'tis. How's that? I shrugge with desire to learne it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
That shrugge is performed by lifting vp both shoulders exactly together with one vniforme motion, somewhat swift, and holding them a while in suspence, with the necke somewhat couching, and the chinne thrust out, then the shoulders are to bee let downe againe, as it were by a double pulley, with a
slow motion, which by degrees vanisheth. And if you will accomplish it with a grace, you must all the while cast your eyes into a leering posture.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O excellent schoole of vertue! But when must I vse this shrugge?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Vpon diuers occurring cases, very vsefully. But especially when you are ask't a question, which you cannot deny with safety, nor assent vnto with honor. In such a two-forked dilemma, the shrugge relieues you, and you come off with reputation of wisedome.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: This is an oracle to mee, I pray you expound by example.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Put case that some faire and honourable Lady were mentioned at the Table, and thereupon some busie curious Gentleman should aske you whether there past no tearmes of loue betweene you and her. To deny it, were a derogation from your honour. To loue or be belou'd is honourable. For you to acknowledge it, were perhaps dangerous. Some of the company may be your Riuall, and so rusty iron may leap out of the Ecle-skin, and pricke your skinne. Thus Venus may be exchanged for Mars. And of the two, hees the most dangerous companion to a mans naked side. One shrugge quits all this, by which you seeme to say, I am not to bee examined vpon this Intergatory. I stand vpon my guard, all arm'd in silent wisedome.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Incomparable dogments. Mus●us neuer taught me so good a lesson.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: But high time it is for vs to appeare, the Session is begunne by this. The villaine Praco is like death, and will spare none. Mee thinks I heare him cry, Captaine Complement appeare. Goe Coach it vp with your Mother. I and my

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: will march vp the hill on foot. Here sir, I appeare sir.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Here sir, at hand. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: SEe how thy soule was snar'd with sophistry.
No Author here alleadg'd for Hedone,
But quels those poysons with their Antidotes.
Marke Tully in that place doth smoothly pleade
For youthfull Calius, so to palliate
His Clyents true obiected vanities.
There Tully plaid the Lawier for his fee.
Behold him now a sage Philosopher:
Discoursing of Old Age, he there concludes,
In voluptatis regno virtutem non posse consistere,
That vertue cannot stand where pleasure raignes.
Anacreon was a wanton Epicure,
A glosing Poet, but lewd Moralist:
He sould his soule to Uenus and her sonne,
Such writers we for stile, not matter reade.
Siren from Terence pleads, that in yong men
Deepe quaffing, roating, whooring, is no fault.
Doth not that Poet represent the parts,
The passions, and seuerall enormities
Of cockering doting fathers, of lewd sonnes,
Of cheating slaues, and cogging parasites?
Thus he describes the vices of those times,
That readers might them hate, not imitate.
S●, Comique Poets set out drunkennesse
In him that pleads for Bacchus, and the while
Doth swagger, stagger, swallow, wallow, snort,
The soule▪ that this picture is, the more
That swinish vice breeds loathing of it selfe.
If I would on a Comique stage display
Vertue in conflict stoutly labouring,
And then in conquest honoured by fame;
First would I personate her enemy
In some such busie guiles and forgery,
As this lewd Siren represents to thee.
The rest of Authors, Motiues, Arguments,
Which in that letter you so stood vpon,
Are of no better stampe, as I haue showne.
And can farre more at large.
But why should I distrust thy iudgement so?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: You haue, judicious Philoponus,
More hardly in the groue, more briefly here,
Dispel'd those mists, which that inchanting witch
Had cast before mine eyes. I see, I see
The light of reason, then eclipsed quite,
But now reuiueing my recouered sight.
O how I loath, and hate that iuggling hand,
That wrote, or teach't to me these balefull lines.
What sacrifice to Vertue can I yeeld
More or, then thus to teare that robe, wherein
That poyson was conuey'd, to be to me
As was the deadly shirt to Hercules?
So would I also her.
sp.stage: He teares thee letter, and stampes on it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Your best reuenge on her will be henceforth,
No more to speake with her by word or pen, Weomens faire words worke deep with passiue men

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What heaps of thankes owe I, and cannot pay, To such a faithfull other selfe, whose hand Hath reached forth that Ariadnes thred Which me out of this Labyrinth hath led.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Come let vs vp into Apollos Court. The Session is long since begunne. There shall you more confirme your resolution, by hearing Apollo himself in his iudgment seate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I Tell thee againe, I haue no great hope of it. You haue suffered so many repulses, that if I were in your case— Where is he. So ho. Come along, mend your pace. What? haue you the gout?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Alas in foot, and hand too. My father and grandsire had so.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Stand vp for shame. Else how will you appeare in Apollos presence, so much as to present your request.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Well. I'le stretch my limbs so farre, though I bee already tyred with our long iourney.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: A long iourney from your Cottage to Apollos Court? when your Tent is fixed but on the other side of the wall. A man may fling a horse loase so farre.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p:
I'le rather bee fed with horse bread, then trauaile so farre againe to fetch whitebread. But I
pray you let vs sit downe. I shall talke much wiser, sitting then standing.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Doe not Iudges sith as now Apollo does there. And I hope they are wiser, then those that stand to heare them.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I judge standing, that thou hast little vnderstanding that art such an enemy to standing.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: But sir Drudo, why doe you discourage mee from hope of admittance?

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: The truth is, I see no great reason why you should be admitted. I'me sure for these seuen yeeres, euery visitation day you haue bin shut out of doores by Musaeus as soone as euer hee espyed you lying vpon the bench in Apollos Court. And for the most part, when your name hath bin called aloud by Praco, you haue bin asleepe, and were faine to be ioggd and shak'd againe before you would answer.
Out vpon thee, what art thou in a Lethargy? I thinke thy mother was asleepe when thou wast begotten. So bo. So bo. I tell thee againe, after seuen repulses, why shouldest thou knocke at Apollos gate.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I dare not knocke at this gate▪ the hammer that hangs on it, is so cold and heauy. And why should I disquiet the Muses with such a noise? Perhaps some of them are asleepe in Apollos lap.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Thou Dormouse, thou liu'st in a perpetuall winter: think'st thou them like to thee?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I cannot climbe this hill. I pray fetch Apollo hither. Or be you Apollo.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What shall Drudo be so bold. No. But say what thou canst. Apollo sees and heares all things in all places.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Why then Apollo. Drudo, I craue admittance.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What is your clayme?

sp.speaker: Slug
sp.p: I am the top of my kin. I am Slim Slugge, Sluggy Sluggorum.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What's that to your plea? Are you a kinne to the Muses.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I haue long prescription time out of time. I haue bin entertain'd euermore by some of Apollos prentises. They haue kept me and sed me in their chambers, and hug'd me in their bed. I neuer wanted among them, those that would rather rest with me in a cold morning, then dance after the Muses pipe with benum'd hands and chattering teeth.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: All Wines haue some lees,
All Bee-hiues some droanes.
Think'st thou that such prescription shall get thee admittance?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I am weary of sitting. I thinke it were better for me to lye downe vpon this banke. I shall talke much wiser yet when my head lyes lower then my heeles, for then all my spirits and wits sinke downe into my braine. So I'le tell thee now what learn'd counsaile I gaue to a young schollar, when he told me that his Master chid him for keeping his bed. Why (quoth I to him) then answer your Master, I pray you sin, would you haue me all my bed? your law, that you giue vs, is, Nil dabis, aut vendes.—

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Very learnedly applyed to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: When I read lecture to my auditors.—

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Surely then thou giu'st a deepe nod at euery s● point.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I inioyne them, Sell your Bookes, sell your Inkehornes, sell your Candlestickes, sell your Points, but neuer sell your beds. The bed is the seate and throne of a schollar. For contemplation requires quietnesse. And when is a man more quiet, then when he is in 〈◊〉 bed? Ergo.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Spoken like a Philosopher, but of the Epicures sect.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Nay you shall haue Philosophy vp to the elbowes. The bed is the beginning and end of a man. When we come into the world, are not our Mothers said to be brought to bed? When we dye, are not we on our death bed? Whil'st we liue, when are we more innocent then when we are asleepe in our bed? then wee thinke no body any hurt. When are mischiefes done by men, but when they are awake, and imploy themselues most busily? Ergo.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: It seemes so by thee, for thou art seldome awake thus long, but to doe some such mischiefe at to talke in this manner.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: The best Philosophers haue said, and I haue heard it in Apollos schoole. Motus fit propter quietem. Nature intends motion, that it may attaine rest. And all schollars know, that what is desired, as the end, is better then that, which is ordained as the meanes to it.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Nay siria, the best of them say, that motion is better then rest. For the heauens moue continually, and the earth, which is the dregs of the world, that rests, and slugs like thee. The day is for labour, and the night for rest. And I hope the day is farre better then the night. Ergo.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Well. I haue all the earth on my side: I'me safe enough. Goe you and dance after the starres. I'le hold my rest here.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Enough of this Philosophy. Thou lolling lubber, lasie Bough, get vp, Rise old huncks, rise drunken Beare, or I'le goe in without thee.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: A Beare? no. I'me a worthier beast, by my hardly rising. I am like an Elephant.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I wood thou hadst a Castle vpon thy backe, then I wood hang thee out for a signe, and it should bee call'd the drowsie Inne. Come away, your name it call'd ere this at the Session, and Praco woon't sauour you. You will be in, forty Markes in issues.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: My turne is alwayes last. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: S●spbu. Scopas. Come away with the Cushions. Lay that Carpet smoother. When were these Cushions brusht. Sirra. ha?

sp.speaker: Scop.
sp.p: I haue heard say, that too much brushing will we are them out.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Thou Lozell. Hath Slugge infected you? Why doe you giue such kinde entertainement to that cobwebbe?

sp.speaker: Scop.
sp.p: It shall haue Tom Drums entertainement. A flap with a Foxe tayle.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p:
For the preparing this Iudgement seate. I pronounce iudgement of banishment against all presumptuous Cobwebbes. The Court will rise, and
come vpon vs ere we are aware. Scopas goe see how forward they are, and bring away the Frankinsence.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: WHere are they, that say that Ludio is the Canker of the schoole? I haue pronounced a knocking Apology before Apollo and all his Court.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: What, nimble Ludio, is the Session so farre on?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Vnto thee, O Thuriger, I am the Nuntio, to tell thee, that Apollo and his Actors are by this time come to Actus quintus, Scena quarta Praco told me they will all come downe hither to Act Scena ultima.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I shall be ready for them. But I pr●, Ludio, how did Mistresse Gingle behaue her selfe?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: She neuer ceased crying out to Apollo, O the generous Captaine Complement! O that he may bold ●is Tenement. Apollo himself was faine to command her silence.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Did not Siren creepe into the soules of the auditory?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: My friend Siren slid on smoothly, like my feete vpon the ice. I thinke shee has vnbent Apollos bow. She will haue a good day of it, I hope. Yong Gingle in his triall stood much vpon his gentry, and carried himselfe like a fine dancing Courtier. When I heard Slugge call'd, I thought we should tarry long, and so away came peelegarlicke Ludio, to get him a roome before hand here.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: But thou tellest me nothing all this while of thy owne tryall. Were you not put to it shrewdly?

sp.speaker: Ludio
sp.p: I trow I put Apollo and all his Muses to it. There can no sentence passe against me. My defence was so strong and vnanswerable.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I am sorry that my office called mee away from hearing you, will you doe mee the honour to impart to me some of your discourse?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I haue it here ingrossed and recorded.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I wonder how you could borrow so much time from play, as to compose so large a declaration?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I haue a ●end in a corner, I teach him the knacks of gaining, how to cut a bum card, how to helpe a dye, and such like, and he in kinde requitall has drawne an Apology for me in forme of Law, according to the stile or Apollos Court.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Could you before all them pronounce it lustily, as if it had bin your owne making?

sp.speaker: Ludio
sp.p: I haue a certaine vertue called audacity. I hat did beare me our where my wit or memory failed.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I ●ng to heare some of it. Can you say it?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: So, so: As we doe our lessons, with a casting a leere eye sometime vpon my paper.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: It is l●ge. I will no 〈◊〉 ●le thee to say it ouer. Onely reade I pray you some of the principall points.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I tell thee here be aboue a dozen of points. You shal haue a touch of the fore-point thus.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I haue knowne the time when you haue had neither fore not ●d point, when you haue return'd from spurne point.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p:
First, I look't grauely like Cato, and withall, cheerefully like Puerilis And then to show what confidence I had in my cause, I strok't vp my foretop with the combe of my finders thus. My sister had
sprinckled it with rose water, and my lips too, to make my Rhetoricke the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: No doubt rose water added a sweet sound to your words.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Then I made obeysance thrice, with a nimble low stoope which I learn't when we plaid at Ducke Fryer. Then I cried ●m, ●em to cleare my voice, and to prouoke the Auditory to answer mee with their gentle expectation.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Here is a large Entry to a low house.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Then displaying my naked protesting hands, I said. O thou louely Lord of learning, beauteous, bounteous Apollo.
sp.l: O thou euer mouing Phoebus,
Whose golden lockes and siluer bow,
Embellish heauen and earth below.
O yee assistant sisters One,
Attend this iust defence of mine.
sp.p: What law, what iustice, what reason can pronounce a gainst Ludio the sentence of expulsion? Is not Apollos Schoole stiled ladus literarius. Is it not Schola from {non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman} otium, remedy, play, relaxation? What talke we of Apollos Court. The whole world is made free of Ludios Trade, and dances after his pipe.

What is our life but a game, wherein some winne, some lose, some idly looke on, some haue good fortune, and will not be known of their winnings, others haue bad lucke, and curse their starres and fates; Some cheate and eke, and others are befooled?
All Dame Natures lumpe is a true Ludio. If you banish Ludio, you must banish the heauens and elements.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: What? is this brat become a Philosopher?

sp.speaker: Ludis.
sp.p:
The highest fixed starres, what doe they all the yeere but dance their measures, and keep there
their stately distances, and, to shew their mirth and wantonnesse, they with their glaring eyes twinckle on their spectators. The Planets haue variety of dances, sometime graue Pauins, otherwhile amble Galliards.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: ●e Sellingers round.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Now a pace forward, now retyring backward.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Like a new Corranto.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: What sayest thou Thuriger? did not I play the Astronomer well?

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Better then sixteene Almanacke-makers, with all their Sextile aspects, and fiery triplicities.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: But now sir here was I put to my trumpes, when I came to bring in our Lord Phoebus himselfe for an example, in my owne defence, in his owne presence. Therefore I begun with crauing pardon. O Maiestique Lord of the day, Moderator of the yeere, Ring-leader of all the glittering lampes; giue poore Ludio leaue to shew that in the worke of thy bright Regiment, thou canst not be without him. Dost thou not all the yeere long recreate thy selfe by taking the ayre about the hill of heauen in thy guilded Caroch, drawne with foure prancing horses?

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Some mortals now adaies haue in their Coach more horses then Don▪ Phoebus.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: In this thy yeerly iourney thou art so frolicke euery spring, that thou giuest our mother earth a greene Downe.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.l: That is (our Virgins say)
A pretty kinde of play.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: And in thy iournall circle when thou comest and goest, euery day and night, mee thinkes thou playest at 〈◊〉▪ peepe, and Hide and seeke.
sp.l: All night it our all hid. But in the day
We seeke about. For what, say I, but play?

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: O Impudency! How durst thou base flea, skippe thus high into Apollos face. Didst thou not feare to be pierced through with the least dart of his beames?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: The truth is, one of Apollos learned Councell had like to pull'd me downe, when he told me that it was against law to produce the Iudge for a witnesse. Else I had gone on to alledge his playing at Quoits with Cyparissus.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: He would haue cond you small thanke for that. But, how did our Lord Apollo looke vpon you all this while?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Me thought hee put his hand toward his quiuer, and withall, shaked his golden lockes. Then thought I, 'twas time for me to glide downe lower, and talke of Lady Luna. Mistresse Moone (quoth I) what is her monethly taske, but to runne a gossipping throughout all the twelue signes in the high street of the Zodiacke?.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: The signe of the Ram, the Bull: the Lion, and the rest, they are Tauernes set vp by Bacchus, for the gods to feast in. Are they not?.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: She knocks at euery doore, & tarryes two daies at the least in each of those houses. And as the Sunne courts her, shee makes curtsies in her round walke, sometimes bashfully putting on her Maske.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: That is in coniunction.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Otherwhile she shewes her halfe face very demurely.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Halfe moone; like my cheese.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: And after that appeares her broad Owles face, to allure Endymion to be in loue with her.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: The Shepheard with the bush of thornes has preuented sleepy Endymion, and gotten vp thit● before him.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: The waues in the sea, what doe they, but play at trusse and leapfrogge on one anothers backe? The winds in the are performe one perpetuall exercise, and that is blow-point.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Sometimes they blowest the points of steeples, and this is a very high point, worth consideration.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: They play very merrily: and therefore wee often heare them ●g and whistle.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Leaue of now your rehearsall Ludio. Why prated you of the starres and winde●? What's this to you, and to those creatures that haue bound themselues to the schoole trade? Doe the Mules play?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Yes vndoubtedly, the Nine Muses play at Nineholes: euery Muse hath her hole

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Yes, and euery Hate hath her Muse. But what then becomes of the ten h●e?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: That's a great one for Apollo their Master and ours.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Thinkst thou, that Apollo will bee mooued with these reasons, to let such a vermine harbour in the pigeon house of the Mr?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Doe you thinke that I will sucke their egges? Doe I looke like a su● 〈◊〉? I am sure the Auditory did entertaine thy speech with the signe of approbation▪ hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: That was 〈◊〉 but the yonger sort, and those that stood at the lower end of the Session hall.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I am much 〈◊〉 taken if Apollo himselfe did not in the end hum and 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I thinke rather Apollo frown'd on you.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: I thinke rather that Mercury frowned on me.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Why Mercury? he is not there.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p:
I'le tell thee, honest Thuriger, Whilst I was in
the heare of my pleading, some Villaine, borne vnder the Planet Mercury, nims away my sachell that lay behinde me.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: What losse suffered you in that vessell?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: The Shipwracke of all my best houshold-stuffe, and tooles of my trade. What thinke you, Thuriger, does this forebode ill lucke to me?.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I thinke it had bin better lucke, if you had bin rob'd of those Commodities seuen yeeres agoe. But see yonder comes my Scopas.

sp.speaker: Scopas.
sp.p: THey are comming hard by. Here is the frankinsence. Put it in your selfe.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: This fire is almost out, stirre it vp.

sp.speaker: Scopas.
sp.p: Laurell wood doth soone spend.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.l: Apollos iudgement seate
Makes all things pure and neat. Apollos iudgment, &c.

div.head: Actus quintus. Scena sexta et vltima.
div.stage: Thuriger. Scopas. Drudo. Lauriger. Praco. Musaeus. Clio. Euterpe. Philoponus. Amphibius. Siren. Ludio. Implement. Slugge. Geron. Retro. N●ce.

sp.speaker: Lauriger.
sp.p: COme along, come on in ranke.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: On afore, On afore▪ Hold vp the booke. Giue roome, roome, more roome.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: We must haue roome, more then the whole City of Rome.
Clio, you must sit down, and you Euterpe. Musaeus craues your assistance.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Praeco doe your office.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: Silentium: et Tacete. Our Lord Apollo by his deputed Iudge, the venerable Musaeus, doth command silence, and chargeth all, whom it may concerne, to attend the Court, and heare the charge

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.l: Our great Apollos Pallace seemeth like
A spacious gard'n set with choysest flowers,
Wherein creepe vp by small vnleene degrees
Vnusefull, hurtfull, and vnsauory weedes;
Which ouergrow and choake the better plants,
And make the tender flowers to hang the head.
Himselfe chiefe Gardner hath, from yonder top
Of this our sacred hill, euen now oe'r-view'd
All that his herbage, and with curious eye
Discerned and designed by his doome,
What must be cherisht, and what weeded out.
Me, his vnworthy seruant, he appoints,
As vnder-gardiner, with that wholesome hooke.
To check, or nip, or toot vp what he dam'd.
To me by oracle he did vnfold,
What lot attends on euery name inrold.
Praco, read the Record, and cite the names.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: Memorandum. On Apollos Shroueday, being the eight and twentieth of Aquarius, in the great hall of the westerne top of Parnassus. Our soueraigne Lord Apollo sitting in person vpon oyer and terminer, after full hearing of all parties, did then and there adiourne the Court, to be presently continued at the foote of the said h●, vnder the Lawrell, at the Temple gate, and to be there consummate by his reuerend Iudge Musaeus.
Nomina Reorum.
The names of the parties sentenced by Apollo.
Siren, the first is Siren. Appeare Siren Spinster.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: She spinnes nothing but spiders webbes, to catch flyes.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Siren come out What doe you lurke? Appeare in your likenesse, and heare your doome.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Vous hauez Si●.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: I haue a great deale more to say for myselfe, and for my Lady Hedone. I hope, I shall be heard.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: You would faine be heard; because you thinke your tongue inchants. There is no pleading now. Apollos doome is past.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: You must heare the Iudge, or else bee prest to death presently.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Siren, then thus for Siren.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Record the sentence Praeco.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: My penne is as nimble as your tongue.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Siren must first be searcht.

sp.speaker: So
sp.p: Sacred dispencer of Apollos iustice, I hope you will not suffer a poore Nimph to be vsed so immodestly. If I must be ransackt, I pray you let it be done by a Iury of Muses. The three Graces, empanneld with them, will make vp the whole number of twelue good weomen, and true.

sp.speaker: Clio
sp.l: If I be made fore-woman of your iury,
You shall be doom'd by iustice, not by fury.

sp.speaker: Irpe.
sp.l: We Mus● enuy no man,
Much lesse will wrong a woman.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Wee shall not need to trouble you noble Clio▪ nor you sweet Euterpe. This search is onely of her vpper garment. Lauriger lift vp her vaile.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Come, I must loue, and court thee now.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: O vgly a filthy fishes taile.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Pull off her head of yallow lockes.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: O blacke bristles. O nasty Vermine!

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: This seeming glosing Nimph is nothing else, but an vgly sea▪ Monster. She is dam'd to returne to the sea, and there to be tossed, and doussed, together with Scylla, that monstrous shame of nature. But, before you kicke her out, let her take a message to carry to Dame Hedone, if ere they meete againe. That is, that Hedone shall euer vnseparably bee manacled to Lupe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O iust doome, that pleasure shall bee alwaies fetter'd to paine. Which also this false Siren prooues. ●irst, a face seeming faire to meet with: but if you further goe, turpem desinit in piscem mulus formosa superne.

sp.speaker: Laur. Drudo. Praco. Philop Omnes.
sp.p: Out with her.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I will haue one kick more at her for inueigling me: Out Bitch.— Exit Siren.

sp.speaker: Muscus.
sp.p: On Praco. Who is next?

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: The next is Ludio. Appeare Ludio Gamester. Vous bauez Ludio.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Here appeares poore banckrout Ludio. I haue suffered losses by misfortune.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What misfortune? fire? or theeues?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I sir. Theeues, they haue rob'd mee of all my brasse coine, and vnbound paper bookes. I must set vp with a new stocke.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The rogue meanes his cards and counters.

sp.speaker: Muscus.
sp.p:
Thou bold else, that canst not at thy triall for
get thy play. Apollo fits thee with a doome, that thou shalt play vncessantly.

sp.speaker: Ludio
sp.p: I'me glad of that A perpetuall play-day.

sp.speaker: Muscus.
sp.p: And thou shalt ●ue fifty playfellowes.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: So much good company does the better.

sp.speaker: Muscus.
sp.p: They are the fifty daughters of Danaus; whose play is still to fetch and fetch water in a sieue. Thou must play still at dice.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: At dice? that's well▪ Ile cheate all those fifty wenches.

sp.speaker: Muscus.
sp.p: But thus. Thy dice thou must put into a bottomlesse boxe. So, when thou throwest, they fall to the ground: and thou must take them vp: they fall againe, thou stoopest againe. This is the M●ll bothering, wherein thou must runne ●und eternally.

sp.speaker: ●il.
sp.p: He that would finde Lu●, must seeke him at the signe of the Labour in va●e.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: O would I had studied when I played▪ rather then thus to play at lost labour eternally. Exit.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Mistresse Indulgence 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Blinde fortune hath quit her of that; but shee is true to her name Indulgence.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: Mistresse Indulgence Gingle. Spinster.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: All the wooll and flaxe, that euer she spunne, I will eate and feare no choaking.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Doth she not appeare?

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: She scowred away in her Coach with her sonne, and said she would dwell no longer in Thessaly, if her sones best instructor be not suffered here. And as she fled, her Coach ouerturned.

sp.speaker: Muscus.
sp.p: Let her foure wheeles carry Apollos curse with her, that none of her kindred shall euer get aboue the petty forme of Apollos schoole. Passe of Praco.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Iohn Gingle, Gentleman Woo'd-be.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Apollo pronounceth that his lot must be, before he be forty yeeres old, to spend all his fiue Mannors vpon the fiue Sences: Except the Mansion house of Foolingham, which is intailed to the heires of his body woefully begotten.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For my part I will not be of counsell to cut off the entaile.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Complement, pretended Captaine, alias Captaine Comp. Fashionmonger.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: He is fled, as I heare.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Fled with a witnesse. For he flew like a bird vp in the aire.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Then has he sau'd vs a labour. For Apollo had doom'd him to be blowne vp with Vulcans bellows into the middle Region of the ayre.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: The boyes in the outer-court of Apollos Pallace, when they perceiued by Mistresse Gingles discontent, that the Captaine was like to be banished, they preuented execution, by tying squibs to his skirts; which being fired, this light ●usball mounted vp into the ay● as high as a larke.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: One boy said, that this was the Captaines lofty capering tricke.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: And whither did this whirle winde carry him?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Who knowes? But most doe thinke to the Iland of Coxcombria, a place thicke impeopled with such rifferaffe.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Iacke Implement, Page to the aforesaid Complement. Vous hauez Implement.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: Here sir, at hand. I pray you Master Musaeus be good to a poore Page. I had but a hard seruice vnder him My bed and board was scarce to the mountenance of a water-Spanniell. I would saine goe to schoole againe.

How right this boy meetes with Apollos doome Thy lot is for the schoole againe: but there for one whole yeere thou must smooth out the dogs care● of all thy fellowes bookes; And vow to ply thy booke as nimbly as euer thou didst thy Master Apery, or the hauty vaulting horse.

sp.speaker: Imp.
sp.p: I vow, and will. Else let mee ●ide our blinde horse that kickes vs on the backe.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What Slugge, could you not come along with vs? You must be lagge. An houre will scarce serue you, though your iourney be short, and downe the hill.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Soft fire, sweet mault

sp.speaker: Musaeus
sp.p: The next name Praco.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Slim Slugge.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Answer to your name.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Hum. ha▪

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He will not answer, vnlesse you giue him all his titles. Sluggus Sluggorum. Sl●e of Slugge-hall.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Why then Slim Slugge, Sluggum Sluggorum, Slugg of Slugge-hall, Sleeper.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Vous hauez Slugge. Stand forth and attend the sentence.

sp.speaker: Muscus.
sp.p: Thou night-bird, in whose nasty nest all Bookes and Inkehornes, and all things else are mouldy, but thy bed. Yet there dost thou pigge in, and pigge out, without molesting the feathers by concussion.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Stand vpright, and leaue thy yawning.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Thou that neuer mayest infect the Muses habitation, Apollo doth banish thee into Lubberland.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Lubberland? I'me glad of that. I shall earne my fourteene pence a day there by snorting. But who shall carry me thither?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, you must foot it thither, there lyes the marrow of your punishment.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: O that I had Tom Cortats euerlasting shooes! But ho which is the way to Lubberland? Has none of you bin there Will you goe with mee? will you in the frize coate? It is a fine Country. There are riuers of Muskadine, and bridges of Brawne, parkes of Ven●▪ son Pasties, paled about with puddings and sausages. Hay for our towne, hey for Lubberland.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Praco, I thinke thou dreamest of Lubberland. Why do not you passe on?
Yong Nouice, Apprentice.

sp.speaker: Nouice.
sp.p: Here. I pray sir, saue me: I'le get my Mother to end ye. 〈◊〉 up a couple of Capons.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Because thou art a free man, and thy follies come of simple 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, and are not deepely rooted in thee, there is hope of thy recouery. for three yeeres thou shalt pay but an houre in the weeke, and all thy schoole time 〈◊〉 depart from the presence and guidance of Philoponus. Obserue and imitate his painfull diligence: so shalt thou get the Muses loue, and Lord Apollo fauour.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Thankes, many▪ thankes to him, and thee for this your clemency.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Good your Worship, be good to my sonne, his Mother will runne madde for gri●.

sp.speaker: Mas
sp.p: Thy sonne▪ Come hither Retro.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Ferem doo●is.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Mercy sir, mercy.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p:
Apollo has accepted thy submission, and cu● of the third yeere of thy punishment. Arise, and shew
thy face, Thy tongue may now runne right, & speake as others doe. You may be a forward childe.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Thankes, O most forward thankes, for the restoring of my distorted limbes and tongue.
Retiring Crabbe farewell. Welcome humane pace.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: But see thou holdst the schollars euen path, nor striding fast, nor wandring from the way.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Thankes sacred Priest I shall bring my wife ioyfull newes.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Now is Apollos garden weeded quite,
Compos'd in order, swept, and cleanly dight.
Now may each tender plant, and goodly flowre
Grow vp, and th●e, by heauens assisting power.
Praco, dissolue the Session.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Oyez, Our soueraigne Lord Apollo, hauing held and finished his Visitation, dischargeth all suiters, parties, and homagers from their attendance in this place; and licenseth all his subiects and seruants, to depart to their seuer all habitations.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Uincat Apollo. Regnet Apollo.

sp.speaker: Clio.
sp.l: It ioyes my heart, that we poore Muses,
Now haue redresse of our abuses.

sp.speaker: Euterpe.
sp.l: Before alas I mournd and wept:
But now I ioy: our schoole is swept.,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Vincat Apollo, Regnet Apollo.

lg.l: Accept (we pray) our hasty huddled games;
Who thus imploy our parts, our paines most gladly,
In hope to please our Mother Towne of Haly.
And thus with this our homely shrouing dish,
A merry Shrouetide to you all we wish.
T●s late▪ Me thinkes I spye some drowsie head,
Whose yawning, nodding toles a peale to bed▪
If any such be here, wee'le take them napping,
And all to boxe their eares with loud hand-clapping.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
